--- title: "Categorical Data — Student Reference" subtitle: "Descriptive summaries & visualizations (freq, proportion, crosstabs, bar/pie/mosaic/waffle)" description: | A student‑friendly reference with concise explanations, runnable examples, and copy‑paste templates for analyzing and visualizing categorical data in R. format: html: toc: true toc-depth: 3 number-sections: true code-tools: true # show copy button code-fold: false theme: cosmo smooth-scroll: true editor: source execute: echo: true warning: false message: true error: true knitr: opts_chunk: comment: "#>" --- # Learning goals - Recognize and work with **categorical variables** in R. - Summarize categories using **frequencies** and **proportions** (a.k.a. relative frequency). - Create standard plots for categorical data: **bar**, **stacked bar**, **pie**, **mosaic**, and **waffle**. - Read and interpret **cross‑tabulations** (two‑way tables) with row/column/table proportions. ::: callout-tip Use the **Copy** button on each code chunk. Many chunks include a **template** version followed by a **worked example**. ::: # Setup ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # install.packages("tidyverse") # install.packages("ggmosaic") # mosaic plots # install.packages("waffle") # waffle charts # install.packages("ggtricks") # geom_pie() # install.packages("ThemePark") # optional themes library(tidyverse) library(ggmosaic) library(waffle) library(ggtricks) library(ThemePark) library(csucistats) ``` ::: ## Data for this handout We will use the **Great American Coffee Taste Test** survey data from TidyTuesday. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true"} coffee <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2024/2024-05-14/coffee_survey.csv") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ## Using the templates: what to change Use this legend whenever you see a **Template** code block. - **`DATA`** → replace with your data frame/tibble name (e.g., `coffee`). - **`VAR`** → replace with the **single categorical variable** you want (e.g., `caffeine`). - In `ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR))`, write `ggplot(coffee, aes(x = caffeine))`. - In functions that take a vector (e.g., `cat_stats(DATA$VAR)`), write `cat_stats(coffee$caffeine)`. - **`VAR1`** and **`VAR2`** → replace with the **first** and **second** categorical variables for two‑way tables/stacked bars (e.g., `caffeine`, `taste`). - **`DF` / `wdf` / `df_pie` / `waffle_df`** → these are **intermediate objects** created in the chunk. You can keep the same names or rename them; if you rename, update the subsequent line that uses them. - **`group = 1`** → keep this as‑is for one‑variable proportion bar charts; it ensures correct normalization. ### Quick replace checklist 1. Swap **`DATA`** for your data frame (usually `coffee`). 2. Swap **`VAR`** for your categorical column (e.g., `caffeine`). 3. For two‑variable templates, set **`VAR1`** and **`VAR2`** (e.g., `caffeine` and `taste`). 4. If you change any intermediate object name (like `df_pie`), update it on the next line as well. ### Tiny example **Template** ```r # Frequency bar (template) ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR)) + geom_bar() ``` **Filled‑in** ```r # Frequency bar (coffee example) ggplot(coffee, aes(x = caffeine)) + geom_bar() ``` **Template** ```r # Crosstab row proportions (template) cat_stats(VAR1, VAR2, prop = "row") ``` **Filled‑in** ```r # Crosstab row proportions (coffee example) cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, coffee$taste, prop = "row") ``` # Categorical data 101 **Categorical data** record membership in a set of categories (levels), e.g., "Yes/No", "Major", or "City". - Stored as text (character/factor) **or** as codes like `1, 2, 3` with a **codebook** describing the labels. # One‑variable summaries ## Frequency (counts) **Definition:** number of observations in each category. **Template:** ```r # Replace DATA$VAR with your variable # freq table (counts) cat_stats(DATA$VAR) ``` **Example:** caffeine preference (`coffee$caffeine`) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cat_stats(coffee$caffeine) ``` ::: ## Proportion (relative frequency) **Definition:** share of the sample in each category; comparable across sample sizes. **Template:** ```r # proportions only cat_stats(DATA$VAR) ``` **Example:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cat_stats(coffee$caffeine) ``` ::: # Bar plots ## Frequency bar plot **Template (frequency):** ```r # ggplot() + geom_bar() counts rows per category by default ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR)) + geom_bar() ``` **Example:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(coffee, aes(x = caffeine)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](test_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Relative frequency bar plot **Template (proportion):** ```r # after_stat(prop) computes proportions within the layer ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR, y = after_stat(prop), group = 1)) + geom_bar() ``` **Example:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(coffee, aes(x = caffeine, y = after_stat(prop), group = 1)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](test_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: callout-note **Tip:** Add labels/theme as needed: `labs(x = "", y = "Proportion") + theme_minimal()` ::: # Two‑variable summaries (cross‑tabulation) Suppose `taste` records whether participants like the taste of coffee. ## Read the marginal distribution ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cat_stats(coffee$taste) ``` ::: ## Cross‑tabulation (two‑way table) - **Rows**: categories of one variable - **Columns**: categories of the second variable - Report **counts** or **proportions** by **table**, **row**, or **column** **Table proportions** (each cell ÷ grand total): ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, coffee$taste, prop = "table") ``` ::: **Row proportions** (each cell ÷ its row total): ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, coffee$taste, prop = "row") ``` ::: **Column proportions** (each cell ÷ its column total): ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, coffee$taste, prop = "col") ``` ::: # Stacked bar plots **Template:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Stacked counts by default; map fill to the second variable ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR1, fill = VAR2)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ::: **Example (stacked counts):** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(coffee, aes(x = caffeine, fill = taste)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](test_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **Example (horizontal):** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(coffee, aes(y = caffeine, fill = taste)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](test_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **Template (stacked proportions):** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Use position = "fill" for per‑x proportions ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR1, fill = VAR2)) + geom_bar(position = "fill") + labs(y = "Proportion") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ::: # Pie charts (use sparingly) **Note:** Pie charts can be harder to compare precisely than bars. If you use them, label clearly. **Template:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Derive counts then draw a pie using ggtricks::geom_pie() df_pie <- cat_stats(DATA$VAR, tbl_df = TRUE)$table ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(df_pie, aes(cat = Category, val = n, fill = Category)) + geom_pie() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'df_pie' not found ``` ::: ::: **Example:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} coffee_pie <- cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, tbl_df = TRUE)$table ggplot(coffee_pie, aes(cat = Category, val = n, fill = Category)) + geom_pie() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](test_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Mosaic plots A mosaic plot shows a two‑way table with rectangle areas proportional to counts. **Template:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # ggmosaic uses product(VAR1, VAR2) in aes(x = ...) ggplot(DATA) + ggmosaic::geom_mosaic(aes(x = product(VAR1, VAR2), fill = VAR2)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ::: **Example:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(coffee) + ggmosaic::geom_mosaic(aes(x = product(caffeine, taste), fill = taste)) + labs(x = "caffeine × taste", y = "") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](test_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Waffle charts A waffle chart is a 10×10‑style grid where each square often represents 1%. **Template:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Build a counts table then call geom_waffle(); set make_proportional = TRUE waffle_df <- cat_stats(DATA$VAR, tbl_df = TRUE)$table ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(waffle_df, aes(fill = Category, values = n)) + waffle::geom_waffle(make_proportional = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'waffle_df' not found ``` ::: ::: **Example:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} coffee_waffle <- cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, tbl_df = TRUE)$table ggplot(coffee_waffle, aes(fill = Category, values = n)) + waffle::geom_waffle(make_proportional = TRUE) + labs(x = NULL, y = NULL) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](test_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Quick troubleshooting - **My bars are sorted alphabetically but I want a custom order.** Convert to `factor` with ordered levels, e.g., ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} coffee <- coffee %>% mutate( caffeine = factor(caffeine, levels = c("No caffeine", "Low", "Medium", "High")) ) ``` ::: - **I only see one bar.** Check that you mapped `aes(x = VAR)` to a **categorical** variable; if it’s numeric with many unique values, you may want bins (histogram), not a bar chart. - **Proportions don’t sum to 1.** Did you use `group = 1` with `after_stat(prop)` (for one‑variable bars) or `position = "fill"` (for stacked)? # Appendix: minimal templates (copy‑paste) Each template below has **placeholders** in ALL CAPS (e.g., `DATA`, `VAR`, `VAR1`, `VAR2`). Replace them with your own dataset name and variable names. ::: callout-important **How to customize placeholders:** - `DATA` → the name of your dataset (e.g., `coffee`). - `VAR` → a single categorical variable (e.g., `caffeine`). - `VAR1`, `VAR2` → two categorical variables for cross‑tabulations (e.g., `caffeine`, `taste`). ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Frequency table cat_stats(DATA$VAR) # replace DATA with dataset, VAR with column name ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Proportions only cat_stats(DATA$VAR, prop_only = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error in cat_stats(DATA$VAR, prop_only = TRUE): unused argument (prop_only = TRUE) ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Bar: frequency ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Bar: proportion ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR, y = after_stat(prop), group = 1)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Crosstab counts cat_stats(DATA$VAR1, DATA$VAR2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Crosstab proportions cat_stats(DATA$VAR1, DATA$VAR2, prop = "table") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cat_stats(DATA$VAR1, DATA$VAR2, prop = "row") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cat_stats(DATA$VAR1, DATA$VAR2, prop = "col") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Stacked bar (counts) ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR1, fill = VAR2)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Stacked bar (proportions) ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR1, fill = VAR2)) + geom_bar(position = "fill") + labs(y = "Proportion") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Pie df_pie <- cat_stats(DATA$VAR, tbl_df = TRUE)$table ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(df_pie, aes(cat = Category, val = n, fill = Category)) + geom_pie() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'df_pie' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Mosaic ggplot(DATA) + ggmosaic::geom_mosaic(aes(x = product(VAR1, VAR2), fill = VAR2)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Waffle wdf <- cat_stats(DATA$VAR, tbl_df = TRUE)$table ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'DATA' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(wdf, aes(fill = Category, values = n)) + waffle::geom_waffle(make_proportional = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` #> Error: object 'wdf' not found ``` ::: :::
